title: Plastic exposure may be making bacteria resistant to drugs
image_caption: Tiny plastic shards of different colors scattered on a light blue background.

title: Microplastics May Contribute to Antibiotic Resistance
Medical infusion bags can release microplastics
Microplastics could be fueling antibiotic resistance
Medical Infusion Bags Can Release Microplastics, Study Shows

Microplastics, from 1 to 62 micrometers long, are present in filtered solutions in medical intravenous (IV) infusions. Study estimates that thousands of plastic particles could be delivered directly to a personâ€™s bloodstream from a single 8.4-ounce (250-milliliter) bag of IV infusion fluid.

Bacteria exposed to microplastics have become resistant to multiple types of antibiotics commonly used to treat infections. This is especially concerning for people in high-density, impoverished areas like refugee settlements, where discarded plastic piles up and bacterial infections spread easily
